{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10234,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Prunus americana, commonly known as the American plum, requires consistent but moderate watering to thrive. It's important to keep the soil slightly moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant deeply once a week, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between watering sessions. During the hotter months or in dry spells, increase frequency to ensure the plant doesn't become too dry. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering. Always consider the plant's environmental conditions, and adjust watering if the weather is excessively rainy or dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prunus americana thrives best in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day to promote healthy growth and fruit production. In areas with hot summer climates, providing a little afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorching. However, too much shade may result in reduced flowering and fruiting. When planting Prunus americana, choose a location that receives ample sunlight throughout the growing season to ensure robust performance and optimal fruit yield."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Prunus americana in late winter or early spring before the plant begins to bud. This helps to remove any dead or diseased wood, which can improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, fostering healthier growth. Focus on thinning the interior branches to allow light to reach the center of the plant. Remove any crossing or rubbing branches, as well as any suckers that may emerge at the base of the tree. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make precise cuts and reduce the risk of infection. Regular pruning will enhance the plant's productivity and shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American plum","description":"Prunus americana, commonly called the American plum, wild plum, or Marshall's large yellow sweet plum, is a species of Prunus native to North America from Saskatchewan and Idaho south to New Mexico and east to Québec, Maine and Florida.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["American plum"],"pest_susceptibility":["Black knot","Brown rot","Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Prunus americana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10636,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cirsium vulgare, commonly known as the spear thistle, is quite drought-tolerant and does not require frequent watering. It prefers well-drained soil and can thrive with minimal water once established. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's essential to ensure the soil dries out between waterings. In periods of prolonged drought or extreme heat, you may need to water it occasionally, ensuring the soil gets a deep soak but allowing it to dry completely before watering again. This plant is well-suited to areas with low natural rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cirsium vulgare thrives best in full sun conditions, meaning it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It is adapted to open spaces such as grasslands and pastures, where sunlight is abundant. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal growth, and flowering occur under full sun exposure. In shaded areas, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Therefore, when planting Cirsium vulgare, select a site that receives plenty of direct sunlight to ensure vigorous growth and robust flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cirsium vulgare should be done to help manage its spread and maintain the plant's shape. After the flowering season, which typically occurs from late spring to early summer, cutting back spent flower stalks can prevent unwanted seed dispersal. This can be important as the plant tends to spread prolifically. Additionally, any dead or damaged leaves should be removed throughout the growing season to maintain plant health and appearance. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid transferring diseases between plants."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bull Thistle","description":"Cirsium vulgare, the spear thistle, bull thistle, or common thistle, is a species of the Asteraceae genus Cirsium, native throughout most of Europe (north to 66°N, locally 68°N), Western Asia (east to the Yenisei Valley), and northwestern Africa (Atlas Mountains). It is also naturalised in North America, Africa, and Australia and is an invasive weed in some areas. It is the national flower of Scotland.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","North Africa"],"other_name":["Bull Thistle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Cirsium vulgare"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11937,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lupinus variicolor, like most lupines, prefers well-drained soil and should not be over-watered. Water the plant moderately, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings, especially during its growing season in the spring and early summer. Reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant becomes dormant. Be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot, particularly if the soil does not drain well. A layer of mulch can help retain moisture in the soil but ensure it does not touch the stem to prevent rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lupinus variicolor thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to fewer blooms and leggy growth. When choosing a planting location, ensure the site receives ample direct sunlight to maximize flower production and overall plant health. In regions with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching and reduce water loss. However, providing ample sunlight is crucial for robust growth and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lupinus variicolor involves removing spent flower spikes and damaged or dead foliage to encourage a healthy plant and promote further blooming. Cut back flower stalks to the base after they have faded to redirect energy into growing strong foliage and roots. In the fall, trim back any dead growth as the plant goes dormant in preparation for winter. Regularly inspect the plant for any signs of disease or pest damage and remove afflicted areas promptly. Pruning also helps maintain the plant's shape and supports healthier, more vibrant blooms in the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Varied Lupine","description":"Lupinus variicolor (varied lupine, manycolored lupine, Lindley's varied lupine or varicolored lupine) is a shrub in the lupine (lupin) genus Lupinus.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California"],"other_name":["Varied Lupine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Lupinus variicolor"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10235,"attracts":["Bees","Flies","Beetles"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hydnum repandum, commonly known as the hedgehog mushroom, typically grows in wooded areas and does not require traditional plant care like watering as it is a wild-growing fungus. However, preserving its habitat involves maintaining natural soil moisture levels. If cultivating similar fungi or ensuring their habitat thrives, consider simulating the forest environment by keeping the ground covered with compost or leaves to retain moisture without waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hydnum repandum naturally grows in shaded, forested areas where sunlight is dappled. To replicate these conditions, if cultivating similar fungi, ensure they receive indirect sunlight. A location under trees or in shade-loving plant beds can mimic the natural forest lighting. Avoid direct sunlight as it might dry out the fungi and affect their growth. Ensuring a canopy or some cover is crucial for maintaining the microclimate they thrive in."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As a fungus, Hydnum repandum does not require pruning like terrestrial plants. However, if foraging or harvesting, ensure that the mushrooms are cut at the base rather than pulling them out to avoid disturbing the mycelium. This allows for continued growth and sustainability of the fungus in its natural environment. Regularly check the growth area and remove any debris or fallen branches that might impede mushroom development."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wood Hedgehog","description":"Hydnum repandum, commonly known as the sweet tooth, wood hedgehog or hedgehog mushroom, is a basidiomycete fungus of the family Hydnaceae. First described by Carl Linnaeus in 1753, it is the type species of the genus Hydnum. The fungus produces fruit bodies (mushrooms) that are characterized by their spore-bearing structures—in the form of spines rather than gills—which hang down from the underside of the cap. The cap is dry, colored yellow to light orange to brown,...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","North America","Japan"],"other_name":["Wood Hedgehog"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Hydnum repandum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11836,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Elymus repens, also known as common couch or quackgrass, is a hardy perennial grass that typically does not require much watering once it is established. It generally thrives on rainwater and can tolerate drought conditions once mature. However, in extremely dry periods or in its early growth stages, regular watering may be beneficial. The soil should be allowed to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent waterlogging, which the plant does not tolerate well. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure well-draining soil is used to prevent this issue."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Elymus repens thrives in full sun but can also tolerate partial shade. Ideally, it should receive around 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day for optimal growth. While it can grow in somewhat shaded areas, its growth may become less vigorous without sufficient sunlight. In full sun conditions, it typically grows more robustly, giving it a competitive edge in its habitat. Thus, while some shading won't harm the plant, providing ample sunlight ensures healthier, more controlled growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning or controlling Elymus repens is more about managing its growth rather than traditional pruning. This grass can be quite invasive, so regular cutting back can help manage its spread. You may need to mow or trim it regularly to keep it in check. In a garden setting, consider removing unwanted rhizomes or dividing the grass clumps to prevent it from overtaking other plants. Consistent and thorough removal of new shoots is essential to control this plant's vigorous spreading nature."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Quack Grass","description":"Elymus repens, commonly known as couch grass, is a very common perennial species of grass native to most of Europe, Asia, the Arctic biome, and northwest Africa. It has been brought into other mild northern climates for forage or erosion control, but is often considered a weed.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["Quack Grass"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root knot nematodes"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Rhizome Division"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Elymus repens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12035,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Nymphaea alba, commonly known as the European White Water Lily, grows best in still or very slow-moving water bodies. The plant does not require additional watering if it is kept in a pond or similar environment, as it naturally thrives with its roots submerged underwater. It is important to ensure that water bodies where Nymphaea alba is planted maintain a consistent water level, especially during hot, dry seasons. If kept in a container or tub indoors, ensure the water level remains steady and fill up with clean water as needed to cover the roots fully."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nymphaea alba requires full sunlight to partial shade, performing best when exposed to at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. The plant naturally thrives in open water bodies where sunlight can reach its leaves easily. In shaded environments, it might produce fewer blooms and slower growth. If grown indoors or in partially shaded ponds, consider relocating the plant to a sunnier spot or adjusting the surrounding environment to ensure it receives adequate light exposure to flourish and produce ample blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Nymphaea alba involves removing dead or dying leaves and spent flowers to promote healthy growth. This can be done throughout the flowering season by gently cutting the leaves and stems back to the base where they meet the rhizome. Regular pruning prevents decay in the water, which can deplete oxygen levels and harm the plant and other aquatic life. It’s also advisable to thin out the foliage periodically to ensure that the plant does not overcrowd the water surface, which helps maintain a balanced aquatic ecosystem."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"European White Waterlily","description":"Nymphaea alba, the white waterlily, European white water lily or white nenuphar, is an aquatic flowering plant in the family Nymphaeaceae. It is native to North Africa, temperate Asia, Europe and tropical Asia (Jammu and Kashmir).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia","North Africa"],"other_name":["European White Waterlily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Rhizome Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Nymphaea alba"],"soil":["Clay","Loam","Silt","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Afternoon"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10836,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Papaver rhoeas, commonly known as the common poppy, prefers well-drained soil and should be watered sparingly. During germination or particularly dry periods, watering is necessary to keep the soil moist but not waterlogged. Once established, these plants are drought-tolerant and require minimal watering. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. Ideally, water the plants in the morning so any excess moisture on the foliage has time to evaporate during the day, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Papaver rhoeas thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to perform its best. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure ensures the most vibrant blooms and healthy growth. In climates with intense heat, some light shading during the hottest part of the day can prevent stress, although the plant is known to be heat-tolerant to some extent. Providing optimal sunlight conditions will support the poppy's natural growing cycle and enhance its aesthetic appeal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Papaver rhoeas generally does not require extensive pruning. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can encourage prolonged blooming and prevent self-seeding if that is not desired. To do this, cut back the flowering stems just above a leaf node or set of leaves. At the end of the growing season, allow foliage to die back naturally, as this helps the plant store energy for the next season. Any diseased or damaged growth should be removed promptly to maintain the health of the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common poppy","description":"Papaver rhoeas (common names include common poppy, corn poppy, corn rose, field poppy, Flanders poppy or red poppy) is an annual herbaceous species of flowering plant in the poppy family, Papaveraceae. This poppy is notable as an agricultural weed (hence the common names including \"corn\" and \"field\") and after World War I as a symbol of dead soldiers.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["common poppy"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Papaver rhoeas"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11735,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erythronium californicum, commonly known as the California fawn lily, prefers consistently moist soil, particularly during its growing season in the spring. It is crucial to keep its soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Typically, this means watering deeply once a week, though this depends on your climate and soil conditions. If the plant is grown in pots, ensure drainage holes are not blocked. As the plant enters dormancy in the late spring to summer, reduce watering significantly to avoid rot, allowing the soil to dry out almost completely till the next growth cycle."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erythronium californicum thrives in partial to full shade, reflecting its natural understory habitat in wooded areas. It benefits from dappled sunlight or morning sun followed by afternoon shade, which mimics the forest settings it is accustomed to. In regions with hotter climates, providing protection from intense afternoon sun is crucial, as too much direct sunlight can scorch the leaves. If planting in a garden setting, consider placing it under deciduous trees, which offer protection during its active growth period and ample light as the trees are bare in early spring."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Erythronium californicum is minimal and mostly involves removing spent blooms and leaves. This helps the plant conserve energy and prevent the spread of any diseases. As the flowering period ends, deadhead the blooms to encourage root growth rather than seed development. Once the foliage begins to yellow and die back, it can be trimmed down to ground level. Leave healthy foliage intact as long as possible, as it will photosynthesize and nourish the bulb for the next growth season. Overall, pruning is more about maintaining plant health than shaping."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California Fawn Lily","description":"Erythronium californicum (common name California fawn lily) is a species of flowering plant in the family Liliaceae, endemic to moist woodland habitats in the mountains of Northern California.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["California Fawn Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Erythronium californicum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11138,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carpobrotus chilensis, also known as ice plant or sea fig, is drought-tolerant and prefers dry conditions. It requires watering only when the soil is completely dry. Overwatering can cause root rot, so it is essential to let the topsoil dry out between watering sessions. During the growing season, reduce watering frequency slightly, and in winter, water sparingly as the plant goes dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carpobrotus chilensis thrives in full sun conditions, which means it should receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. It is ideal for planting in sunny spots, such as rock gardens, slopes, or coastal areas where the sun is abundant. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can soak up ample sunlight. Limited sunlight can hinder flowering and stunt growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carpobrotus chilensis involves trimming back any leggy or overgrown stems to maintain a tidy shape and encourage denser growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10334,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Clematis lasiantha prefers moderate watering, as it is a drought-tolerant plant. Water the plant deeply once a week, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Deep watering encourages the development of a robust root system, which helps the plant withstand dry periods. Avoid overhead watering to prevent fungal diseases and instead aim to water at the base. During hot, dry spells, more frequent watering may be necessary, while less water is needed during cooler months. Always ensure that the plant is well-drained to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clematis lasiantha thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of sunlight per day to support healthy growth and vibrant blooming. Morning sun with afternoon shade is particularly beneficial in hotter climates to protect it from intense, direct sunlight, which can scorch the leaves. If grown in an excessively shaded location, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer blooms. Ensure the plant's roots are shaded naturally by surrounding foliage, mulch, or strategically placed stones to keep them cool and promote optimal growth conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clematis lasiantha promotes healthy growth and abundant flowering. This plant benefits from a hard prune during the fall or early winter, after it has finished flowering. Cut back the stems to just above a pair of healthy buds. Remove any dead or damaged wood to encourage new growth. In early spring, as new growth begins, thin out weak or overcrowded stems to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration. Regular pruning helps prevent tangling and maintains the plant's desired shape and size, while encouraging more prolific blooms in the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pipestem Clematis","description":"Clematis lasiantha, the pipestem clematis, is a creamy-white flowering liana vine, belonging to subgenus Clematis of the large Clematis genus.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","Baja California"],"other_name":["Pipestem Clematis"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Clematis lasiantha"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When cultivating or managing this plant in a controlled environment, it is essential to avoid over-watering as it prefers drier soil once established. In dry summer conditions or dry habitats, occasional deep watering can help promote root growth but should be done sparingly to prevent root rot and maintain the plant's natural hardiness."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Toxicodendron diversilobum can adapt to a range of light conditions but typically flourishes in partial shade to full sun environments. It's important, however, to handle and manage its location carefully due to its toxic properties, keeping it away from high-traffic areas or places where humans and pets frequently traverse."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Toxicodendron diversilobum should be approached with caution due to its irritating sap, which can cause skin reactions. Dispose of cuttings carefully, and wash tools and any exposed skin immediately after pruning. Always prioritize safety, and if the plant poses a health concern or significant hazard, consider consulting with professionals."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pacific poison oak","description":"Toxicodendron diversilobum (syn. Like other members of the Toxicodendron genus, T. diversilobum causes itching and allergic rashes in many humans after contact by touch or smoke inhalation.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Pacific poison oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Anthracnose","Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Toxicodendron diversilobum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Once the blooming period has ended and the leaves have begun to yellow and die back, you should trim back the spent flowers and any dead foliage. Excessive moisture can lead to bulb rot, so ensure proper drainage. During the dormant phase in summer, refrain from watering entirely, allowing the soil to dry out completely. Resuming watering in late winter or early spring encourages the plant to break dormancy and start a new growth cycle."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fritillaria biflora thrives in full sun to partial shade. Once the flowering period ends in late spring to early summer, you can remove spent blooms to maintain the plant’s appearance and to prevent unnecessary energy expenditure on seed formation. Allow the foliage to die back naturally as they are essential for storing energy for the next growing season. When all foliage has turned yellow or brown, you may gently remove the dead leaves. Be cautious not to damage the bulb as it remains underground and stores vital nutrients to support the plant’s next cycle of growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chocolate Lily","description":"Fritillaria biflora (chocolate lily, mission bells) is a species of fritillary native to western California and northern Baja California. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10237,"attracts":["Pollinators","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Spiraea tomentosa, known as steeplebush, prefers consistently moist soil, making regular watering important, especially during dry spells. Ideally, you should water it whenever the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Avoid letting the soil completely dry out, as this can stress the plant. Mulching around the base helps retain soil moisture, reducing the frequency of watering needed. However, ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, as standing water can be detrimental. Adjust watering frequency based on rainfall and the specific soil conditions in your garden."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spiraea tomentosa thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, aim to provide at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. When planted in areas with full sun, the plant tends to have more vibrant blooms and a denser form. If placed in partial shade, ensure that the area receives significant morning sunlight to fuel its growth. While it does tolerate some shade, too much can lead to leggy growth and reduced flower production. Placement in a sunny spot will yield the best ornamental results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Spiraea tomentosa helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged branches first, cutting them back to healthy wood. You can also reduce the overall size or shape the plant by cutting back up to one-third of the oldest branches to the ground. This promotes vigorous new growth and ensures that the plant remains dense. Pruning after flowering will prevent seed formation and can encourage a second round of bloom in some climates."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Steeplebush","description":"Spiraea tomentosa, commonly known as the steeplebush, meadowsweet, or hardhack, is a plant similar in characteristics to S. douglasii.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Steeplebush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Spiraea tomentosa"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid cutting back the plant too severely, as it could stress the fern and hinder its growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"marginal wood fern","description":"Dryopteris marginalis, vernacularly known as the marginal shield fern or marginal wood fern is a perennial species of fern found in damp shady areas throughout eastern North America, from Texas to Minnesota and Newfoundland. It's adapted to dry climates, so it's best to let the soil dry out slightly between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure good drainage. During the hotter months, you might need to water more frequently, but always check the soil moisture first. In cooler months, reduce watering since the plant enters a more dormant phase and requires less moisture. Remember to adjust your watering habits based on your local climate and weather conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Monardella villosa thrives best in full sunlight, which is essential for its optimal growth and vibrant flowering. This plant is native to open, sunny habitats, so it needs at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. If grown in partial shade, it may become leggy and produce fewer blooms. In extremely hot climates, providing some light afternoon shade can help prevent foliage burn. However, make sure the shade is not too dense, as the plant's overall vigor and bloom capacity might diminish if it doesn't receive enough sunlight. Proper sunlight is crucial for healthy flowering and fragrance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Monardella villosa, or coyote mint, involves cutting back the plant in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. This helps to promote healthy growth and a fuller appearance. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration. After its blooming period, you can also deadhead spent flowers to encourage more blooms and prevent self-seeding, which helps maintain its vibrant appearance. Be careful not to over-prune as this can stress the plant. Regular, gentle pruning will keep your Monardella villosa healthy and attractive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Coyote Mint","description":"Monardella villosa is a plant in the mint family which is known by the common name coyote mint.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","California"],"other_name":["Coyote Mint"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Monardella villosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10639,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cirsium brevistylum, commonly known as short-styled thistle, prefers consistent moisture but requires well-drained soil to prevent root rot. Water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells, but allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering. Water deeply at the base to ensure that the moisture reaches the roots. In cooler climates, reduce watering frequency during fall and winter months when the plant's growth slows. Similarly, ensure good air circulation around the plant to reduce humidity and prevent fungal diseases, taking care not to overwater and create overly soggy conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cirsium brevistylum thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to grow robustly and produce vibrant blooms. Although it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure ensures optimal growth and flowering. In regions with extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the plant from becoming scorched. Consistent sunlight helps maintain its compact, healthy form, and promotes the best flowering display. When planting, choose a location with ample direct sunlight, and ensure the site is not shaded by nearby plants, trees, or structures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cirsium brevistylum involves removing spent flowers and damaged foliage to maintain plant health and appearance. After blooming, deadhead by snipping off faded flowers to encourage more blooms and reduce seed spread. At the end of the growing season, cut back the stems to a few inches above the ground to prepare the plant for dormancy. Regularly check for any signs of disease or pest infestations and prune affected parts immediately. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts, thereby minimizing the risk of infections or entry points for pests."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Short-styled Thistle","description":"Cirsium brevistylum is a species of thistle known by the common names Indian thistle and clustered thistle. It is native to western North America having been found in southwestern British Columbia, Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Montana, and California.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Short-styled Thistle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Cirsium brevistylum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Remember, this plant thrives in arid environments, so it prefers dry conditions over being too wet."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chaenactis stevioides thrives in full sunlight, which aligns with its native desert habitat. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10436,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Triteleia laxa, commonly known as Ithuriel's Spear or triplet lily, does not require regular watering, especially in areas with winter rainfall. In its native habitats, it relies on seasonal rain, so mimicking this cycle is ideal. Water the plant occasionally during the growing season in spring if the soil appears dry, but avoid waterlogging since the bulbs can easily rot. Once flowering is complete and the foliage starts to die back in summer, reduce watering and allow the soil to dry out during dormancy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Triteleia laxa thrives best in full sun to light shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to bloom optimally. While it can tolerate partial shade, less sunlight may result in fewer flowers and elongated leaves. Gardeners in very hot climates might consider providing partial afternoon shade to protect the plant from excessive heat. When planted in containers, place them in a location that captures the morning sun and dappled afternoon light for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Triteleia laxa is minimal, primarily focused on maintaining appearance and encouraging future blooms. After the plant flowers, it is best to let the foliage die back naturally because it provides energy to the bulbs for the next growing season. Once the leaves turn yellow and dry, they can be trimmed back at the base. Avoid cutting the foliage while green, as this can inhibit the plant’s growth in subsequent years. Removing spent flowers can promote a tidier look."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Ithuriel's Spear","description":"Triteleia laxa (previously Brodiaea laxa) is a triplet lily known by several common names, including Ithuriel's spear, common triteleia and grassnut. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11040,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Geranium pratense, commonly known as meadow cranesbill, requires regular watering, particularly during dry spells. The goal is to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. It is important to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent root rot. During the growing season in spring and summer, it might need watering once or twice a week, while in the cooler months, reduce the frequency. Paying attention to weather conditions and adjusting accordingly is key to providing adequate hydration for this plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Geranium pratense thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal flowering and growth. However, in regions with intense afternoon sun, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and stress. In shadier areas, while the plant may survive, the flowering will be less prolific. Finding a balance where it receives bright, indirect light with some direct exposure will yield the best results for this hardy perennial."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Geranium pratense involves deadheading spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming and prevent self-seeding. After the flowering season, which typically ends by mid-summer, you can perform a more significant prune by cutting the plant back by a third to rejuvenate it. This process will promote fresh growth and potentially a second bloom. In late fall or early spring, remove any dead or damaged stems to maintain plant health. Using sharp, sterilized pruning shears helps to ensure clean cuts and prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Meadow Crane's-bill","description":"Geranium pratense, the meadow crane's-bill or meadow geranium, is a species of hardy flowering herbaceous perennial plant in the genus Geranium and family Geraniaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Meadow Crane's-bill"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew","Rust","Leaf spots"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Geranium pratense"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After the flowering period, it is generally safe to allow the soil to dry out completely. However, deadheading spent flowers can encourage a prolonged blooming period and prevent self-seeding if control is desired in a garden setting. Otherwise, little pruning is necessary for its upkeep, and it can often be left to grow naturally. Avoid excessive pruning during its dormant period in the winter months."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fitch's tarweed","description":"Centromadia fitchii, common name Fitch's spikeweed or Fitch's tarweed, is a species of North American plants in the tarweed tribe within the sunflower family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11339,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hordeum brachyantherum, commonly known as meadow barley, requires consistent moisture to thrive but does not tolerate overwatering. It’s crucial to let the soil surface dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. In well-drained soil conditions, this plant can handle fluctuating moisture levels slightly but will prefer more frequent watering during dry or hot weather. In winter, watering should be reduced since the plant's growth slows down, and it requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hordeum brachyantherum prefers full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. However, in cooler climates, full sun exposure is ideal to enhance its growth and flowering. It’s adaptable and can also grow in light shade, but too much shade can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hordeum brachyantherum is not heavily required, but occasional trimming can promote healthy growth and prevent seed spread if that's a concern. After flowering, you can trim back the seed heads to maintain the plant's appearance and control self-seeding. In early spring, before new growth begins, cut back any dead or damaged stems to encourage fresh, healthy growth. It's also beneficial to remove any brown or dead foliage throughout the growing season to keep the plant tidy and to reduce the likelihood of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Meadow barley","description":"Hordeum brachyantherum, known by the common name meadow barley, is a species of barley. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12038,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Platanthera lacera, also known as the ragged fringed orchid, prefers consistently moist soil conditions but does not tolerate standing water. To water this plant effectively, maintain an evenly damp substrate through regular watering practices, particularly during its active growth period in the spring and summer. If you're cultivating this orchid in a pot, ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogging. In its natural habitat, it thrives in moist meadows and marshlands where moisture is abundant, so replicating these conditions will help it flourish. Mist the plant occasionally if the ambient humidity is low."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Platanthera lacera thrives in partial sunlight to light shade conditions, reflecting its natural woodland habitat. Direct, intense sunlight can damage this orchid's delicate foliage and should be avoided. Instead, aim to place the plant in a location where it receives dappled sunlight, such as beneath a canopy or alongside taller plants. This emulates the filtered sunlight it would experience in the wild. Ensure it receives adequate light, especially during the growing season, to support healthy flowering, while protecting it from the harsh midday sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Platanthera lacera is not commonly required since it is a wild orchid species. However, maintaining its health might involve some light grooming. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves to prevent disease and promote a neat appearance. Pruning is best done after the flowering season when the plant is less active. This perennial doesn't require shaping through pruning but rather just basic care to remove spent flowers and dead material. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid introducing pathogens to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"ragged fringed orchid","description":"Platanthera lacera is an orchid in the genus Platanthera, native throughout Eastern United States and Canada. It occurs in a variety of habitats ranging from “mesic and dry-mesic sand prairie, wet sedge meadow, calcareous fen, sphagnum bog, acid seep spring, dry field, mesic flatwoods, and mesic upland forests.” Common names include ragged fringed orchid and green fringed orchid.","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish-white","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["ragged fringed orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Platanthera lacera"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11442,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eschscholzia minutiflora, commonly known as the small-flowered poppy, requires minimal watering, making it ideal for xeriscaping. It is drought-tolerant and thrives in well-drained soil, so ensure the soil dries out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so water infrequently and conservatively, especially after the plant is established. During prolonged dry periods, a light watering can help, but typically, natural rainfall is sufficient to meet its needs. Monitoring the plant for signs of wilting or stress in extreme conditions can help you decide if additional water is necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eschscholzia minutiflora thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to flourish. This hardy plant is well-suited to bright, open locations where it can benefit from unobstructed sunlight, promoting robust growth and abundant flowering. While it can tolerate some light shade, especially during the hottest part of the day, prolonged shade may reduce blooming. When choosing a planting site, consider south or west-facing areas that provide consistent sunlight to ensure vibrant blooms and healthy foliage throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eschscholzia minutiflora is generally not necessary due to its small, compact nature and self-seeding capability. However, to prolong blooming and maintain a tidy appearance, you can deadhead spent flowers regularly. This process involves cutting back the flower stems just above the foliage as blooms fade. Deadheading not only encourages the plant to produce more flowers but also prevents it from going to seed too early, which can extend its blooming period. If desired, at the end of the flowering season, allow some flowers to seed for propagation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Little Gold Poppy","description":"Eschscholzia minutiflora is a species of poppy known by the common name pygmy poppy.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Northwestern Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Little Gold Poppy"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Eschscholzia minutiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10640,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Claytonia perfoliata, commonly known as miner's lettuce, prefers consistently moist soil, so regular watering is essential, especially during dry periods. It is important to maintain even moisture because letting the soil dry out may lead to wilt or stress. However, take care not to waterlog the plant; avoid soaking the soil as miner's lettuce dislikes excessive wetness that can lead to root rot. Checking the top inch of soil and ensuring it stays damp but not soggy is a good guide. Adjust watering frequency based on local weather conditions and seasonal changes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Claytonia perfoliata thrives in partial shade to full sun, but it performs best in cooler climates or shaded conditions where it mimics its natural habitat under trees. In hotter regions, providing afternoon shade helps prevent wilting and extends the growing season. With early morning sun and protection from the harsh afternoon sun, the plant maintains its vigor. If growing indoors, placing it near an east or north-facing window is beneficial, and outdoors, positioning it in a location with filtered shade can ensure optimal growth. However, allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering. This plant is somewhat drought-tolerant once established, so it's essential not to overwater it as it can lead to root rot. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering significantly but do not let the soil dry out completely. Well-draining soil is recommended to ensure excess water drains properly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calystegia occidentalis thrives best in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. While it can tolerate some shade, too little light may result in fewer blooms and a leggier plant structure. If growing in a partially shaded area, ensure it still gets some direct morning or late afternoon sunlight. The plant is well suited to bright, open areas like fences and trellises provided it receives adequate sunlight. Protect it from extreme midday sun in very hot climates to prevent leaf scorch."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Calystegia occidentalis involves regularly removing dead or weak growth to maintain its shape and encourage healthier blooms. It's best to prune in late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Cutting back long stems can help manage the plant's sprawling habit and prevent it from overtaking other plants. Throughout the growing season, remove any spent flowers and trim back unruly vines to promote continuous blooms. Regular maintenance will help control its spread, as this species can be vigorous and invasive in optimal conditions. Be careful and wear gloves, as the plant can cause mild skin irritation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Western morning glory","description":"Calystegia occidentalis is a species of morning glory known by the common name chaparral false bindweed.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Western morning glory"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Calystegia occidentalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Sharpen mower blades regularly to keep cuts clean and promote faster recovery of the grass."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Smooth Meadow-grass","description":"Poa pratensis, commonly known as Kentucky bluegrass, smooth meadow-grass, or common meadow-grass, is a perennial species of grass native to practically all of Europe, northern Asia and the mountains of Algeria and Morocco. However, it is important not to overwater as the plant is susceptible to root rot. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions, and reduce watering frequency during the plant's dormant period in winter. Always ensure that excess water can drain freely away from the pot or bed to prevent soggy conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cymbalaria muralis thrives in a range of light conditions, from full sun to partial shade. It does best in a location with full sun to partial shade, which encourages the most vibrant foliage and flowering. In hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. The plant is quite adaptable to different light conditions, but its flowering might be reduced in deep shade. Ideal placements are often in rock gardens, walls, or areas with dappled sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cymbalaria muralis is minimal but beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging lush growth. Prune the plant annually in the early spring to remove dead or damaged stems and to control its spread. Additionally, periodic trimming during the growing season can help prevent it from becoming too invasive in garden settings. Deadhead spent flowers to prolong the blooming period and to prevent unwanted self-seeding if this is a concern."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Ivy-leaved toadflax","description":"Cymbalaria muralis, with common names ivy-leaved toadflax, Kenilworth ivy, coliseum ivy, Oxford ivy, mother of thousands, pennywort, wandering sailor, is a flowering plant native to Mediterranean Europe and widely naturalised elsewhere.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean Europe"],"other_name":["Ivy-leaved toadflax"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Cymbalaria muralis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11239,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lomatium californicum, also known as California Lomatium, requires minimal watering once established. It is a drought-tolerant plant adapted to dry, rocky environments. During its initial growth phase, regular watering is necessary to help the plant establish a strong root system. However, once matured, it should only be watered occasionally, particularly during extended dry spells. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other water-related diseases. Ensure good drainage to prevent water accumulation around the roots. Adjust watering frequency depending on weather conditions and soil type."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lomatium californicum thrives in full sun conditions, benefiting from at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. This exposure promotes robust growth and vibrant flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, particularly in hotter climates, full sun is ideal for optimal health and flowering performance. In shaded spots, it may experience reduced growth and fewer blooms. Consider the sun’s intensity in different seasons and adjust the plant’s location if necessary to provide adequate sunlight exposure. Ensuring sufficient sunlight is crucial for the plant’s overall vitality and blooming potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Lomatium californicum is not frequently required but can be beneficial to promote healthy growth and shape. Removal of dead or diseased foliage should be done as needed to maintain plant health. Prune after the flowering season, trimming back any spent flower stalks and any excessive growth. This encourages the plant to focus its energy on new, healthy growth and prepares it for the next blooming cycle. Take care not to over-prune as the plant may become stressed – moderate trimming is sufficient to maintain its natural form and vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California lomatium","description":"Lomatium californicum is a species of plant related to the carrot and the parsnip which is known by the common names California rock parsnip, celery weed, and California lomatium....","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","Arizona"],"other_name":["California lomatium"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Lomatium californicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10240,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Liatris pycnostachya, commonly known as prairie blazing star, prefers well-drained soil and is fairly drought-tolerant once established. Water this plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out somewhat between waterings. Too much water can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to ensure that the soil drains well. During the growing season, particularly in prolonged periods of drought, you can water moderately, but avoid over-watering. In winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant goes dormant, and excess moisture can cause harm. Mulching can help retain moisture in the soil during hot days."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Liatris pycnostachya thrives in full sun and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to grow and bloom optimally. It is best planted in an area where it can bask in unobstructed sunlight for the majority of the day. If planted in partial shade, the stalks may grow leggy and fail to stand upright, and flowering may be reduced. Full sun also ensures vibrant flowers and healthy foliage. If growing indoors or in partially shaded locations, consider using supplemental lighting to provide the necessary intensity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Liatris pycnostachya is straightforward and primarily involves removing spent flower spikes and any dead or damaged foliage. Once the flower spikes have finished blooming, you can cut them back to the base to encourage a tidier appearance and sometimes promote further flowering. In late fall, after the plant has fully died back, cut the entire plant down to ground level. This not only tidies the garden but encourages healthy new growth in the spring. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize damage and the chance of disease entry points."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"prairie blazing star","description":"Liatris pycnostachya (prairie blazing star) is a perennial plant native to the tallgrass prairies of the United States. Liatris pycnostachya is an erect perennial found in tallgrass prairie remnants in the Midwestern and Eastern United States. The plant reaches 1–3 ft (0.3–0.9 m) in height \"with numerous ascending linear leaves and magnificent, showy, compact spikes of rose pink blossoms.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["prairie blazing star"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Liatris pycnostachya"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regular pruning helps encourage bushy growth and prevent the plant from becoming overly woody or sparse. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11341,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Koeleria macrantha, commonly known as prairie junegrass, is a drought-tolerant species that thrives in well-drained soils. It requires minimal watering once established, making it suitable for xeriscaping or dry garden conditions. During its first growing season, ensure consistent moisture to help establish its roots. After establishment, water sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other moisture-related issues. Generally, rainfall can suffice in many regions, unless in prolonged drought, where occasional supplemental watering may be necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Koeleria macrantha thrives best in full sun conditions. It requires a minimum of 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to perform optimally. This grass is well-suited to open meadows and sunny prairies and can tolerate a range of light conditions but prefers full sun for fullest growth and the most vibrant foliage. Although capable of withstanding partial shade, prolonged exposure to shady conditions may result in reduced vigor and bare patches. Ensure that your planting site is open and receives ample sunlight to promote healthy development and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Koeleria macrantha is straightforward due to its low-maintenance nature. In early spring, remove any dead or damaged foliage to promote fresh growth and improve the plant's overall appearance. During the growing season, deadhead any spent flowers to encourage tidiness and potentially extend the bloom period. Unlike many other grasses, prairie junegrass maintains a tidy clump without aggressive spreading, so aggressive pruning is unnecessary. If the plant becomes too dense or begins to die out in the center, it can be divided every few years in spring to rejuvenate growth and maintain health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Prairie Junegrass","description":"Koeleria macrantha is a species of grass known by the common name prairie Junegrass in North America and crested hair-grass in the UK. During warmer months, more frequent watering is necessary, while in cooler months, reduce the frequency—but the roots should always be slightly damp. It's beneficial to use room temperature water to avoid shocking the plant, and if possible, utilize distilled or rainwater to prevent any mineral buildup from tap water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Adiantum jordanii thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Consistent light exposure is key, but be cautious during peak sunlight hours to ensure that any harsh rays are buffered by sheer curtains or some form of shading."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Adiantum jordanii involves removing any dead or damaged fronds to encourage healthier growth and maintain a tidy appearance. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut the fronds close to their base, being careful not to damage new shoots. Regularly inspect the plant for faded or browning foliage, especially in lower light areas, and prune as needed. Doing this not only helps keep the plant looking fresh but also allows for better air circulation around the remaining fronds, reducing the risk of pests or diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California Maidenhair Fern","description":"Adiantum jordanii is a perennial species of maidenhair fern, in the Vittarioideae subfamily of the Pteridaceae. It tends to flourish more robustly in full sun conditions, which promote dense growth and vibrant flowering. For optimal flowering and healthy foliage, ensure it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. It benefits from occasional trimming to remove spent flowers and any dead or damaged foliage, which helps maintain a neat appearance and encourages new growth. If the plant is spreading too much or encroaching on unwanted areas, it can be cut back to control its growth. Pruning is best done in early spring before the plant's active growing season, although light tidying can also be done throughout the year if necessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Brass Buttons","description":"The small marsh flower Cotula coronopifolia bears the common names brass buttons, golden buttons, and buttonweed. The flower heads are bright yellow discoid heads that look like thick buttons. Individual plants spread stems along the ground and send up the knobby flowers at intervals. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10841,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crataegus laevigata, commonly known as the Midland Hawthorn, prefers well-drained soil conditions. It is relatively drought-tolerant once established but benefits from regular watering during its initial growth period. Water young trees deeply to ensure the soil remains moist, especially during dry spells. Mature trees generally require less frequent watering, though supplemental watering can be beneficial during prolonged dry periods. Ensure the soil is not waterlogged, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. Consistent monitoring of soil moisture levels can help in determining the right watering schedule for specific growing conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crataegus laevigata thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, provide this plant with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. In too much shade, the tree may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. However, it can tolerate some afternoon shade, especially in regions with very hot summers, to prevent leaf scorch. Planting in an area with good air circulation can also help reduce the risk of fungal diseases. Choose a location that offers morning sun with partial afternoon shade for balanced growth and vibrant flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crataegus laevigata is best done in late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain good air circulation and promote healthy growth. Thinning the interior helps reduce fungal problems by allowing sunlight to penetrate the canopy. Lightly trim back overly long branches to maintain the desired shape and size. Avoid heavy pruning as it can lead to excessive water sprout growth. Regular maintenance pruning will help maintain the health and appearance of the tree while encouraging vibrant blooms in the spring."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"midland hawthorn","description":"Crataegus laevigata, known as the midland hawthorn, English hawthorn, woodland hawthorn or mayflower, is a species of hawthorn native to western and central Europe, from Great Britain (where it is largely confined to lowland ancient woodland) and Spain east to the Czech Republic and Hungary. It is also present in North Africa. The species name is sometimes spelt C levigata, but the original orthography is C lævigata.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["midland hawthorn"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf spot","Fire blight"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Crataegus laevigata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regular inspection is key to maintaining a healthy cultivation environment."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"King Bolete","description":"Boletus edulis (English: penny bun, cep, porcino or porcini) is a basidiomycete fungus, and the type species of the genus Boletus. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10541,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Amaranthus blitum, commonly known as purple amaranth, prefers consistently moist soil. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. In hot and dry weather conditions, you may need to water more frequently, while during cooler months or if grown indoors, the frequency may decrease. It is crucial to ensure good drainage, as waterlogged soil can lead to root rot and other fungal issues. Always check the moisture level before watering, and consider using a mulch to retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Amaranthus blitum thrives in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and leaf coloration, providing at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day is recommended. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample light. In areas with extremely hot or dry climates, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from excessive heat and leaf scorch. If sunlight is insufficient, the plant may become leggy or produce fewer flowers, so consider supplementing with grow lights if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Amaranthus blitum involves removing any dead or yellowing leaves and cutting back old flower stalks after they have bloomed. This encourages the plant to produce new growth and can improve its overall appearance. Regular trimming of the plant can help to control its size and shape, especially if it starts to get leggy or grows beyond its desired size. Additionally, pinching back the stems can promote bushier growth. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent damage to the plant, and prune during its active growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"purple amaranth","description":"Amaranthus blitum, commonly called purple amaranth or Guernsey pigweed, is an annual plant species in economically important plant family Amaranthaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Golden","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean","South Asia"],"other_name":["purple amaranth"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Amaranthus blitum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11740,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erythronium oregonum, commonly known as the Oregon fawn lily, prefers moderate watering regimes. It thrives in moist but well-drained soil, especially during its growing season in spring. Water the plant regularly to keep the soil consistently damp but not waterlogged. It's crucial to reduce watering significantly in the summer when the plant enters dormancy. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent bulb rot. Rainwater is ideal if available, as it maintains natural moisture levels familiar to the plant in its native habitats."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erythronium oregonum thrives best in partial to full shade settings. It is well-suited for woodland gardens or under-story plantings where it replicates its natural growing conditions. Too much direct sunlight can scorch the leaves, so providing morning sun with afternoon shade is ideal. If growing in a garden setting, aim to plant Erythronium oregonum under the protective cover of deciduous trees, which will allow dappled sunlight to trickle through in early spring when the plant is actively growing and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erythronium oregonum is quite minimal, as this plant has a natural, tidy growth habit. After flowering, allow the foliage to die back naturally as it feeds the bulb for next year’s growth. Remove any spent or dead leaves to maintain plant health and aesthetics. It's not necessary to deadhead the flowers because the plant will self-seed if conditions are favorable. Avoid cutting the leaves too soon; leaf removal should only occur when they yellow and start to decline naturally, ensuring robust growth in the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"giant white fawn lily","description":"Erythronium oregonum is a North American species of flowering plant in the lily family which is known by the common name giant white fawnlily or Oregon fawn-lily.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Canada"],"other_name":["giant white fawn lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb division"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Erythronium oregonum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10842,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ribes uva-crispa, commonly known as gooseberry, requires regular watering, particularly during dry spells or drought conditions. The soil should remain consistently moist but not waterlogged, as overly saturated soil can lead to root rot. It's best to water the plant in the morning or evening to reduce evaporation and help the plant retain moisture. During the initial establishment phase, more frequent watering is required, but as the plant matures, it becomes more tolerant of dry conditions. Always check the soil moisture before watering, and adjust the frequency based on the weather conditions and soil type."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gooseberries thrive best when planted in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, they should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with particularly hot summer temperatures, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the plants from getting scorched. Sunlight affects fruit quality and yield, so ensure the site has good exposure. In less sunny conditions, gooseberries might still grow, but they may produce fewer fruits with less intense flavor. Choosing a sunny spot with good air circulation will help in promoting healthy growth and abundant fruiting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ribes uva-crispa is essential to maintain its shape, remove dead or diseased wood, and encourage healthy fruit production. This should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing any overlapping or inward-growing branches to open up the plant's center, which improves air circulation and sunlight penetration. Additionally, prune back the tips of the one-year-old branches (approximately by one-third) to promote branching and increase fruit yield. Regular pruning ensures the plant remains vigorous and productive over the years."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"European gooseberry","description":"The gooseberry (/ˈɡuːsbɛri/ or /ˈɡuːzbɛri/ (American and northern British) or /ˈɡʊzbəri/ (southern British)), with scientific names Ribes uva-crispa (and syn. Ribes grossularia), is a species of Ribes (which also includes the currants).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["European gooseberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew","Gooseberry sawfly"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Ribes uva-crispa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10643,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carduus tenuiflorus, commonly known as slender-flower thistle, is a drought-tolerant plant that thrives with minimal watering. It is adapted to survive in dry, arid environments. When cultivating in a garden setting, water this plant sparingly, ensuring the soil is allowed to dry out between waterings. Over-watering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other issues. Watering deeply but infrequently is recommended, promoting the extensive root system characteristic of this hardy thistle. During exceptionally dry periods, a sparse and light watering every few weeks will suffice to keep the plant healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carduus tenuiflorus thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of bright, direct light each day for optimal growth. This plant is well-suited to open, sunny areas where it can absorb abundant sunlight. While tolerant of partial shade, prolonged exposure to low light conditions might result in less robust growth and fewer blooms. If grown in a garden setting where full sunlight is not entirely possible, make sure the plant still receives at least a few hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain its vigorous growth and flowering capability."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carduus tenuiflorus involves removing spent flowers, dead, or damaged foliage to encourage robust growth and prevent unwanted self-seeding. This thistle can be quite vigorous, so pruning is also key to managing its spread in garden environments. Use gloves to protect against the plant's thorny stems when cutting back. Pruning can be done throughout the growing season to maintain plant shape and health, but be cautious of removing too much at once. Focus on strategic cutting to reduce height or spread. Regular pruning can also help improve air circulation around the plant, reducing the likelihood of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Slender Thistle","description":"Carduus tenuiflorus, known variously as slender-flower thistle, sheep thistle, shore thistle, slender thistle, winged plumeless thistle, winged slender thistle, and winged thistle) is a species of thistle.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Slender Thistle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Carduus tenuiflorus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
