{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10340,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus kelloggii, commonly known as the California black oak, thrives in soil that maintains moisture but ensures proper drainage. While established trees are relatively drought tolerant, young and newly planted specimens require regular watering, especially during prolonged dry periods. A deep watering every 10 to 14 days during the growing season ensures their roots receive adequate moisture. Avoid frequent shallow watering as it encourages roots to stay near the surface. Instead, apply enough water at a slow rate to reach the root zone, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus kelloggii thrives in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure robust growth and optimal health. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially when young, too much shade may lead to leggy growth and fewer leaf productions. When planting, choose a location that receives ample morning sunlight with some afternoon shade, especially in hotter climates. Providing the right amount of sunlight will help maintain its form and color. Ensure it is not overshadowed by larger trees or structures as it matures, as it prefers a more open position as it grows."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus kelloggii should be done primarily during its dormant season in winter, to minimize sap loss and stress on the tree. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or diseased wood to promote healthy growth. Thin out crowded areas to improve air circulation and light penetration, which reduces the likelihood of disease. Avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the tree and stunt its growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and avoid leaving stubs. Training young trees to establish a strong structure is crucial, but leave as much foliage as necessary to support robust growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California black oak","description":"Quercus kelloggii, the California black oak, also known as simply black oak, or Kellogg oak, is an oak in the red oak section (Quercus sect. Lobatae), native to western North America. It is a close relative of the black oak (Quercus velutina) found in eastern and central North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western North America"],"other_name":["California black oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["December"],"scientific_name":["Quercus kelloggii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

While it can tolerate light shade, too little sunlight will result in fewer blooms and potentially leggy growth. Morning glories grow best in an area where they can receive consistent sunlight throughout the day, making them perfect for trellises or fences in sunny gardens."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ipomoea purpurea involves removing any dead, diseased, or damaged stems and leaves to encourage healthy growth. This plant can be pruned back lightly throughout the growing season if it becomes unruly or to promote bushier growth. Deadheading, which means removing spent flowers, can also encourage more blooms. For annual maintenance, cut back the entire plant in late fall if it's grown as a perennial in warmer climates, or remove the plant entirely if it's grown as an annual. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common morning-glory","description":"Ipomoea purpurea, the common morning-glory, tall morning-glory, or purple morning glory, is a species in the genus Ipomoea, native to Mexico and Central America. Like all morning glories the plant entwines itself around structures, growing to a height of 2–3 metres (6 ft 7 in–9 ft 10 in) tall. The leaves are heart-shaped and the stems are covered with brown hairs. The flowers are trumpet-shaped, predominantly blue to purple or white, 3–6 centimetres (1.2–2.4 in) diameter.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["common morning-glory"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Ipomoea purpurea"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It thrives in dry conditions and prefers infrequent watering. During the first year, water your California juniper thoroughly every couple of weeks to help it establish a deep root system. Afterward, watering can be reduced dramatically. Once settled in, it only needs water during prolonged dry spells. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, as it cannot tolerate soggy soil. Checking the soil moisture before watering is a good practice, and only water if the soil is dry at least 2-3 inches down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Juniperus californica thrives in full sun, needing at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. This will enhance its natural growth form and help prevent issues such as fungal infections associated with damp, shady conditions. Protect young plants from intense afternoon sun in very hot regions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Juniperus californica is not typically essential, but it can be done to maintain a desired shape or to remove any dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts. Avoid cutting into old wood, as junipers do not regenerate well from this. Focus on trimming back to a lateral branch or bud, and always prioritize the health of the plant by removing only up to a third of its growth at a time. During the growing season, water sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. In extreme drought conditions, occasional supplemental watering can support growth, but avoid permanent wet conditions. Mulching can help conserve moisture and maintain a stable temperature around the root zone, ensuring healthy plant development without excessive watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Deinandra fasciculata prefers full sunlight, which is essential for its vigorous growth and abundant flowering. Aim to provide at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. This plant is highly adaptable to different sunlight conditions typical of its native range, but the sunnier the location, the better it performs. Insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and reduced flower production. Plant it in an open, unshaded area in your garden to maximize exposure to the sun's rays. Full sun positions also help mimic the plant's natural coastal and inland habitats."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Deinandra fasciculata is generally minimal due to its natural growth habit. However, to encourage bushier growth or maintain shape, it's helpful to pinch back the tips of young plants early in the season. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to promote healthy growth. Deadheading spent flowers might extend blooming and tidy up the plant, but leaving some flowers can support pollinators and natural reseeding. Perform significant pruning in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins, to prepare the plant for the next growing cycle."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Clustered Tarweed","description":"Deinandra fasciculata (syn: Hemizonia fasciculata), known by the common names clustered tarweed and fascicled spikeweed, is a species of flowering plant in the daisy family native to western North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Baja California"],"other_name":["Clustered Tarweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Deinandra fasciculata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid chlorinated or fluoridated water for misting; use rainwater or distilled water instead."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lobaria pulmonaria prefers low to moderate light conditions, as it naturally grows in shaded forested areas. If you're growing Lobaria pulmonaria indoors, consider placing it in a spot that receives indirect sunlight, such as a north or east-facing windowsill. Avoid placing it in areas with strong, direct light exposure, especially during peak sunlight hours, as this can lead to the lichen drying out too quickly and losing its vibrant coloration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically required for Lobaria pulmonaria since it is a lichen and not a vascular plant with stems or leaves to trim. However, if maintaining a neat appearance is desired, or if there are parts of the lichen that appear dead or damaged, gentle removal with minimal disturbance is possible. Use clean, sharp scissors or gently pinch off the unwanted sections. Always ensure that any pruning enhances air circulation around the lichen to prevent mold and other issues related to excess moisture retention. Regular inspection will help keep it healthy and looking its best."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tree Lungwort","description":"Lobaria pulmonaria is a large epiphytic lichen consisting of an ascomycete fungus and a green algal partner living together in a symbiotic relationship with a cyanobacterium—a symbiosis involving members of three kingdoms of organisms. Removing any dead or damaged blades ensures better airflow around the plant base, reducing the risk of disease. Regular pruning also prevents the plant from becoming too invasive, as it can spread aggressively in favorable conditions."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"harding grass","description":"Phalaris aquatica (syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10243,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Amanita muscaria, commonly known as the fly agaric mushroom, is a wild mushroom that is not typically cultivated in home settings like houseplants. In its natural habitat, it does not require specific watering as it absorbs moisture from its surroundings. If one were to attempt cultivation, maintaining a humid environment would be key, mimicking the moist forest floors it naturally grows in. Artificial watering systems should not be used; instead, the environment itself should be kept consistently humid to ensure the necessary moisture levels are met."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"As Amanita muscaria is a mushroom, it does not photosynthesize and therefore does not require direct sunlight for growth. Instead, it thrives in shaded, forested environments under the canopy of trees. If replicating conditions for observation or study, one should ensure it is kept in shaded and cool environments that mimic dappled sunlight reaching the forest floor. Too much direct sunlight would likely dry out the environment and inhibit its growth, so maintaining a shady habitat is critical for its development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Amanita muscaria as it is a mushroom and not a plant that undergoes growth where leaves or branches would require cutting. Instead, its lifecycle involves the emergence from soil, spore dissemination, and natural decay. Unlike plants, mushrooms do not benefit from or require pruning. Therefore, if you come across Amanita muscaria in nature, it should be left undisturbed, both for safety due to its toxic properties and for ecological considerations."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fly Agaric","description":"Amanita muscaria, commonly known as the fly agaric or fly amanita, is a basidiomycete mushroom, one of many in the genus Amanita. It is also a muscimol mushroom. Native throughout the temperate and boreal regions of the Northern Hemisphere, Amanita muscaria has been unintentionally introduced to many countries in the Southern Hemisphere, generally as a symbiont with pine and birch plantations, and is now a true cosmopolitan species. It associates with various deciduous and coniferous trees.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Northern Hemisphere"],"other_name":["Fly Agaric"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Amanita muscaria"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Allow the top couple of inches of soil to dry out between waterings. When in doubt, it's better to err on the side of underwatering. Adequate sunlight also aids in the plant's drought tolerance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lomatium utriculatum is generally minimal as this plant maintains a natural, tidy growth habit. Deadheading spent flowers can help prevent unwanted self-seeding if control over its spread is desired. Additionally, removing any dead or diseased foliage helps maintain plant health and appearance. In late fall or early spring, you can cut back any remaining dead stalks to ground level to encourage fresh growth. Pruning should be done with sterilized tools to prevent the spread of plant diseases. Avoid cutting the leaves unless they are damaged or dying, as they help the plant photosynthesize. There are many varieties of torch lily, and they bloom at different times during the growing season. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10939,"attracts":["Deer","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ulmus rubra, commonly known as the slippery elm, prefers moderate watering conditions. Ensure that the soil remains consistently moist, especially during dry spells, as the elm does not tolerate prolonged drought well. However, avoid waterlogging by ensuring proper drainage, as overly saturated soils can lead to root rot. Water deeply during its growing season and reduce frequency during the fall and winter months when the plant is dormant. Mulch around the base can help retain moisture and provide a stable environment for root growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ulmus rubra thrives best in full sunlight to partial shade. It prefers locations where it can receive a minimum of 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to support its growth and overall health. In regions with very hot summers, the tree may benefit from some afternoon shade to protect it from excessive heat stress. This species is adaptable and can tolerate a range of light conditions, but optimal growth is achieved in bright, sunny locations. Ensure adequate spacing when planting to maximize light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ulmus rubra should be done primarily in the late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain the tree's health and structure. It’s also important to target branches that disrupt the tree's natural shape or prevent sunlight from penetrating to lower branches. Avoid heavy pruning, as this tree naturally has an open, spreading crown that should be retained. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist during its growing season, especially in spring and summer, but avoid over-watering as it can lead to root rot. Allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings. During fall and winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant enters a dormant period. Ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to prevent waterlogging, and adjust watering based on the plant's response and local climate conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gomphocarpus fruticosus thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate partial sunlight, especially in hotter climates, where a bit of afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorching. The more sunlight the plant receives, the better it will grow and flower. Inadequate sunlight may result in leggy growth and fewer blooms. If grown indoors or in a part of the garden with limited light, consider supplementing with a grow light to mimic the full sun conditions that maximize its robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Regular pruning is beneficial for Gomphocarpus fruticosus to encourage a bushy growth habit and remove any dead or damaged stems. Pruning should ideally occur in early spring or directly after flowering to remove spent blooms and encourage new growth. To do this, use clean, sharp pruning shears and cut back any leggy or unkempt branches by about one-third. Additionally, removing seed pods is important if you want to prevent self-seeding and manage the plant's spread in your garden. Always wear gloves when handling, as Sap can irritate the skin."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Narrow-leaf Cotton Bush","description":"Gomphocarpus fruticosus (syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12042,"attracts":["Bees","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Keckiella ternata, commonly known as blue lips or whorled penstemon, thrives in dry, well-draining soil and is generally drought-tolerant. When establishing new plants, provide regular watering to encourage deep root growth. Once established, water sparingly; allowing the soil to dry out between waterings is beneficial. In prolonged periods of drought or extreme heat, occasional deep watering can help maintain plant health. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the plant is not left in waterlogged conditions. Mulching can help retain soil moisture but be careful not to cover the crown of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Keckiella ternata prefers full sun to partial shade for optimal growth and flowering. It thrives best with at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. In areas with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching. Despite its tolerance for varying sunlight conditions, excessive shade can result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. If the plant is grown indoors or in a shaded garden, ensure it receives adequate light by placing it in the brightest spot available or supplementing with grow lights if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Keckiella ternata is beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging bushy growth. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before the plant begins its active growth phase. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote healthy growth. Lightly trimming back the tips of the plant can also encourage a fuller shape. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant and reduce flowering. Regular deadheading throughout the blooming season can help extend the flowering period by preventing energy from being spent on seed production."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"blue-stemmed keckiella","description":"Keckiella ternata is a species of flowering plant in the plantain family known by the common name scarlet keckiella.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California"],"other_name":["blue-stemmed keckiella"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Keckiella ternata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11843,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhizophora mangle, commonly known as red mangrove, is primarily found along coastal areas, usually in saltwater environments. They have adapted to thrive in these conditions, and hence, do not require typical watering like many houseplants do. If growing in controlled conditions, maintain moisture by simulating tidal conditions with brackish water to support their natural habitat. The soil should be kept moist and never dry out completely. Using saltwater or a diluted salt solution can replicate their natural environment, ensuring the water mimics their native saline surroundings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhizophora mangle thrives in full sunlight similar to what they receive in their native coastal habitats. For optimal growth, they require at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily. When growing in a controlled environment, such as a greenhouse, placing them where they receive ample natural light is ideal. If natural sunlight is insufficient, supplemental grow lights can be used to ensure they achieve the necessary light exposure. Providing adequate sunlight supports their photosynthesis process and overall health, enabling these unique plants to flourish."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Red mangroves generally do not require frequent pruning unless being maintained for aesthetic reasons or to manage size in a controlled environment. Pruning can be done to remove dead or damaged branches and to encourage a structure that allows sunlight to penetrate all parts of the plant. If needed, pruning is typically done post flowering. Use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease. It's important to avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the plant, potentially impacting its growth and health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"red mangrove","description":"Rhizophora mangle, the red mangrove, is distributed in estuarine ecosystems throughout the tropics. Its viviparous \"seeds\", in actuality called propagules, become fully mature plants before dropping off the parent tree. These are dispersed by water until eventually embedding in the shallows.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Florida","Caribbean","Central America"],"other_name":["red mangrove"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew","Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Rhizophora mangle"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After the flowering period, which usually occurs in late spring to early summer, cut back the flower stalks to just above the base of the plant. This not only tidies the plant but also encourages new growth and potentially a second bloom. In the fall, once the foliage has died back, cut the entire plant down to the ground level. The soil should be well-draining to prevent root rot, which means avoiding heavy clay soils or improving drainage with organic matter. Mulching can help retain moisture, but be careful not to overwater, as Red Currants are susceptible to root rot if kept too wet."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ribes rubrum requires full sun to produce the best fruit yield, although it can tolerate partial shade. Too much shade may also lead to less vigorous growth and increased susceptibility to diseases. Ensure that the location is not prone to strong winds that can damage branches and interfere with pollination."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ribes rubrum is essential for maintaining plant health and productivity. Prune during late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased wood, as well as cutting back old canes to promote new growth. Red Currant fruits on spurs from two- and three-year-old wood, so maintain a balance by removing older canes to encourage younger ones. A healthy plant should have an open center and well-spaced branches to allow sunlight and air circulation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Red Currant","description":"The redcurrant, or red currant (Ribes rubrum) is a member of the genus Ribes in the gooseberry family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11946,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Festuca rubra, or red fescue, prefers well-drained soil and should not be overwatered. It has moderate drought tolerance once established. During dry periods, especially in hot summer months, water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth. It's important to allow the top few inches of soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other diseases. A general rule is to provide about 1 inch of water per week, either from rainfall or supplemental watering. Adjust this amount based on weather conditions and soil drainage qualities."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Festuca rubra thrives best in cool, shaded to partially shaded areas. It can tolerate full sun, especially in cooler climates, but performs well in shady spots making it ideal for undersides of trees or in low light garden areas. In warmer climates, some shade will help prevent heat stress and drying out. The plant's adaptability to various light conditions makes it a versatile choice for gardens, especially where other grasses might struggle. Ensure it gets some sunlight each day for optimal growth, as it helps with photosynthesis and overall plant vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Festuca rubra is minimal and mainly involves mowing. If used as a lawn grass, mow it regularly during the growing season to maintain a height of around 2 to 3 inches. In naturalized or ornamental settings, allow the grass to grow taller, mowing in late winter to remove dead foliage and encourage fresh growth. This cutting back also helps reduce thatch build-up and improves air circulation. Remove any damaged or diseased blades promptly to maintain plant health. Ensure your mower blades are sharp to prevent tearing the grass which can lead to disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"red fescue","description":"Festuca rubra is a species of grass known by the common name red fescue or creeping red fescue. It is widespread across much of the Northern Hemisphere and can tolerate many habitats and climates. It is best adapted to well-drained soils in cool, temperate climates; it prefers shadier areas and is often planted for its shade tolerance. Wild animals browse it, but it has not been important for domestic forage due to low productivity and palatability....","family":null,"flower_color":"Brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","North Africa"],"other_name":["red fescue"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Festuca rubra"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11543,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dendromecon rigida, commonly known as bush poppy, is drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering once established. It thrives in well-drained soil, and overwatering can lead to root rot. During the first growing season, water regularly to help establish a deep root system. Once the plant is established, usually after the first year, watering can be reduced. In general, aim to water the plant once every two weeks during dry periods, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. It's important to avoid waterlogged conditions to keep the plant healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dendromecon rigida prefers full sun to thrive. It should be planted in a location where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Full sunlight encourages the development of vibrant yellow flowers and promotes healthy growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, blooming may be reduced, and the plant might become leggy as it reaches for more light. Therefore, for best results and optimal flowering, ensure it receives ample direct sunlight. If grown indoors or in a shaded area, consider supplementing with grow lights to meet its sunlight requirements."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Dendromecon rigida should be done to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches, as these can harbor pests and diseases. Lightly trimming the plant can help maintain its desired shape. When pruning, make clean cuts close to the branch collar to ensure proper healing. Avoid heavy pruning, as bush poppy does not regenerate well from woody stems. Regular pruning also helps to control its size and prevent it from becoming too leggy or sparse."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Bush Poppy","description":"Dendromecon rigida, also called bush poppy or tree poppy, is a shrub or small tree of the Papaveraceae native to California and Baja California.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Oregon"],"other_name":["Bush Poppy"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Dendromecon rigida"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11447,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ephedra viridis, also known as Mormon tea, is a drought-tolerant plant that thrives in dry, well-draining soil. It requires minimal watering once established. During its initial growth phase, it is important to water regularly to help establish the roots. Once mature, watering should be reduced significantly, and it can often rely on rainfall. Aim to water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues, so it is crucial to ensure that the plant does not sit in waterlogged conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ephedra viridis prefers full sun exposure and thrives in bright, direct sunlight. It is adapted to arid environments where it receives ample sunshine and can withstand high temperatures. For optimal growth, ensure the plant receives at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily. In areas with particularly intense sun, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent scorching. However, in general, this plant is well-adapted to handling strong sun conditions and requires plenty of light to grow vigorously and maintain its characteristic green stems."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ephedra viridis is not typically necessary, but it can be performed to maintain a desired shape or size. The best time to prune is during the dormant winter months. If structural pruning is needed, it should be done sparingly and only dead, diseased, or damaged stems should be removed. Minimal pruning encourages a more natural growth habit. Because this plant can become bushy, occasional light pruning can help manage its growth and improve air circulation. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent any damage or transmission of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Green Ephedra","description":"Ephedra viridis, known by the common names green Mormon tea, green ephedra, and Indian tea, is a species of Ephedra. This cool-season grass benefits from at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to grow effectively. Optimal growth occurs in open areas where it can bask in ample sunlight. Generally, it should be cut before it reaches a height of 20-30 cm (8-12 inches) and ideally before flowering to maintain a lush, compact appearance. If using Timothy Grass for hay, mow it when the flower heads are fully emerged but before they have shed pollens for optimal nutritional value. Pruning also helps in removing any dead or diseased sections to promote good air circulation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Timothy grass","description":"Timothy-grass (Phleum pratense) is an abundant perennial grass native to most of Europe except for the Mediterranean region. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12043,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Isotria verticillata, also known as the Large Whorled Pogonia, requires a well-balanced watering schedule. It's essential to mimic its natural habitat, which often involves boggy grounds or forest underbrush with consistent moisture but not waterlogging. Ideally, water this plant when the top inch of its soil feels dry to the touch, ensuring the substrate remains fairly consistent in moisture. Avoid letting the plant completely dry out or become overly saturated, as both conditions can be detrimental to its health. It's important to maintain a balance, as a constant moisture level supports its growth cycle."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Isotria verticillata thrives in partial to full shade conditions, akin to its native woodland habitat. It prefers dappled sunlight that filters through a forest canopy, avoiding direct, harsh sunlight which can be detrimental to its health. If grown in a garden or as a potted plant, it's best to place it in an area where it receives morning sunlight or filtered sun through the day, rather than the strong midday or afternoon sun. Maintaining this light condition ensures optimal growth and minimizes the risk of leaf scorch or dehydration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Isotria verticillata is generally minimal, as it doesn't require extensive cutting back like some other plants. It's best to remove any dead or damaged leaves and spent flowers to encourage better airflow and light penetration, which also helps in preventing any potential disease. Since the plant's life cycle includes a period of dormancy, this task is best done after the flowering period has ended and the plant begins to naturally retreat. By removing dead parts, you can channel energy back to healthy growth rather than maintaining non-viable foliage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Large Whorled Pogonia","description":"Isotria verticillata, commonly known as the large whorled pogonia and purple fiveleaf orchid, is an orchid species native to eastern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellowish-green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Large Whorled Pogonia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Isotria verticillata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's crucial to keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Over-watering can lead to root rot, while under-watering can stress the plant and reduce fruit yield. An inch of water per week, including rainfall, is generally sufficient. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering. Always water directly at the root zone to avoid wetting the foliage, which can lead to disease problems."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rubus idaeus thrives best in a location with full sun, which means it should receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. If planted in a shaded area, the plant may become more susceptible to diseases and produce less flavorful berries. Consider planting raspberries in an area that is free from afternoon shade to maximize sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rubus idaeus is essential for maintaining plant health and fruit production. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any weak, dead, or diseased canes. For summer-bearing varieties, prune all canes that bore fruit last season, while for everbearing types, you can remove old and damaged canes or conduct a light prune in the fall. Maintaining an open plant structure allows better air circulation and sunlight penetration, boosting fruit quality and reducing disease risk."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"red raspberry","description":"Rubus idaeus (raspberry, also called red raspberry or occasionally as European raspberry to distinguish it from other raspberries) is a red-fruited species of Rubus native to Europe and northern Asia and commonly cultivated in other temperate regions.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["red raspberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites","Raspberry cane maggot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Rubus idaeus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water this plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. In its first year, water it more frequently to help establish its root system. When mature, it typically only requires watering during extended periods of drought. Be cautious not to overwater, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. Adjust watering frequency based on local climate conditions and rainfall, ensuring that the plant's natural dry environment is emulated as closely as possible."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Justicia californica thrives in full sun conditions, where it can receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. It is ideally suited to desert landscapes where sunlight is abundant, but care should be taken in extremely hot climates to provide occasional afternoon shade if necessary. Inadequate sunlight can lead to poor health or damp conditions that this xeriscape-friendly plant dislikes."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Justicia californica is generally straightforward and should be done to maintain its shape and promote bushier growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged branches to encourage healthy growth. To shape the plant or control its size, trim back the stems by no more than a third of their length. After the main flowering period, deadheading spent blooms can encourage additional flowering. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease transmission. Regular pruning helps maintain a neat appearance and supports overall plant vigor."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"chuparosa","description":"Justicia californica is a species of flowering shrub native to the deserts of southern California, Arizona, and northern Mexico. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11147,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Leucanthemum vulgare, commonly known as the ox-eye daisy, prefers moderate watering. During the growing season, water the plant deeply once a week, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. These daisies are somewhat drought-tolerant and benefit from well-drained soil. In periods of excessive rainfall, ensure that the plant is not sitting in waterlogged conditions. In winter, reduce watering as growth slows, only providing moisture enough to keep the soil from completely drying out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leucanthemum vulgare thrives in full sun conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, too little sunlight can result in elongated stems and reduced blooms. In extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent stress and excessive wilting. However, for cooler climates, full sun exposure is essential to produce the characteristic plentiful and bright flowers of the ox-eye daisy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"To keep Leucanthemum vulgare looking its best, regular pruning is recommended. Deadhead spent blooms to prolong the flowering period and prevent unwanted self-seeding. In late autumn or early spring, cut back the stems to 2-3 inches above the ground to remove dead or damaged growth and encourage fresh, healthy growth in the coming season. If the plant becomes too large or loses shape, divide it every 2-3 years in early spring or early autumn to rejuvenate and maintain its vigor."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"oxeye daisy","description":"Leucanthemum vulgare, commonly known as the ox-eye daisy, oxeye daisy, dog daisy and other common names, is a widespread flowering plant native to Europe and the temperate regions of Asia, and an introduced plant to North America, Australia and New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["oxeye daisy"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf miners"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Leucanthemum vulgare"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After the plant finishes blooming in early summer, deadhead the spent flowers to encourage a second bloom and prevent seed production. In the fall, cut the plant back to about several inches above ground level to tidy up its appearance and prepare it for winter. If the plant starts to appear leggy or overgrown during its growing season, a light trim can help maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Always use sharp, sanitized tools to prevent disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Eastern Beebalm","description":"Monarda bradburiana (eastern beebalm or Bradbury's beebalm) is a species of perennial flowering plant in the mint family, Lamiaceae, that is native to much of the southeastern United States","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Eastern Beebalm"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Monarda bradburiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In regions with intense sunlight, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ambrosia trifida involves mainly controlling its size and spread, as it is a robust plant prone to aggressive growth. Regularly check for any old or damaged foliage and remove them to promote better air circulation and prevent disease. Pinching back the top growth early in the season can encourage bushier growth and improve overall plant structure. This can also help manage its height, which can otherwise reach up to 12 feet. Prune any unwanted seedlings or invasive sections to prevent them from overtaking other plants, given its invasive nature."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"giant ragweed","description":"Ambrosia trifida, the giant ragweed, is a species of flowering plant in the sunflower family. To promote healthy growth, maintain consistent soil moisture without allowing the soil to become waterlogged. It's best to let the topsoil dry out slightly between waterings. It can tolerate partial shade, but insufficient light may lead to weaker growth and less vibrant foliage or flowering. A sunny location will ensure optimal growth and development, maximizing its potential for robust size and colorful display. If grown indoors or in a less than ideal outdoor spot, supplementing with artificial grow lights may help ensure its light requirements are adequately met, especially during the winter months."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Amaranthus albus involves removing any dead or diseased stems to prevent the spread of pathogens and encourage healthy growth. Regular trimming can help control its size, as it can grow quite large if unchecked. Pinch back young stems to promote bushier growth and remove any flowers or seed heads if you wish to prevent self-seeding and invasive spreading. Pruning should generally be done in early spring before new growth starts or as needed during the growing season to maintain the desired shape and size, and to stimulate the plant's vigor."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"prostrate pigweed","description":"Amaranthus albus is an annual species of flowering plant. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve the tree's structure and disease resistance. Regular maintenance pruning will keep the tree attractive and manageable while promoting healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"western sycamore","description":"Platanus racemosa is a species of plane tree known by several common names, including California sycamore, western sycamore, California plane tree, and in North American Spanish aliso. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11347,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eriogonum latifolium, commonly known as coast buckwheat, is drought-resistant and should be watered sparingly once established. During the initial growing season, water regularly to help the plant establish its root system. Once established, allow the soil to dry out between waterings, as overwatering can lead to root rot. In general, water deeply but infrequently, perhaps once every two to three weeks depending on the climate, soil type, and local conditions. Pay attention to signs of over or under-watering, such as wilting or yellowing leaves, to adjust the watering schedule accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eriogonum latifolium thrives in full sunlight, which means it requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to grow optimally. It is well-suited for dry, open, and sunny locations, such as coastal bluffs and sandy soils. Insufficient sunlight can lead to weak and leggy growth, reducing the plant’s ability to produce its characteristic flowers. Therefore, when planting, choose a location that receives ample sunlight, and avoid areas that are significantly shaded by larger plants or structures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Eriogonum latifolium in late fall or early spring to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged stems to allow for better air circulation and light penetration. Cut back the spent flower stalks after they have bloomed to prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively, which helps maintain its aesthetic and prevent invasiveness. Avoid heavy pruning as it might stress the plant; light, regular maintenance pruning is preferred. Remember to use clean, sharp tools to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Seaside Buckwheat","description":"Eriogonum latifolium is a species of wild buckwheat known by the common names seaside buckwheat and coast buckwheat. This plant is native to the coastline of the western United States from Washington to central California, where it is a common resident of coastal bluffs and scrub.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Oregon"],"other_name":["Seaside Buckwheat"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Eriogonum latifolium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11846,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Geranium nodosum prefers moderate watering conditions. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, which is typically spring and summer, water the plant regularly ensuring that the top inch of soil remains moist. Reduce watering in the fall and winter, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Be cautious not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. A good practice is to check the soil moisture with your finger before watering. This plant benefits from a well-draining soil to prevent any standing water issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Geranium nodosum thrives best in partially shaded locations, making it ideal for woodland gardens or shaded borders. It can tolerate full shade, but growth and flowering may be less vigorous. While it can survive in full sun, especially in cooler climates, it benefits from some afternoon shade to prevent the leaves from scorching. If grown in a container, consider relocating the pot throughout the day to avoid prolonged exposure to direct sunlight. Providing a balance of sunlight and shade will promote robust growth and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Geranium nodosum is relatively straightforward, focusing mainly on maintaining its shape and promoting healthy growth. After the flowering period, which often extends through summer, it is advisable to deadhead the spent flowers to encourage a tidier appearance and potentially induce more blooms. Additionally, early spring is an excellent time to cut back any dead or damaged stems, which helps in revitalizing the plant for the new growing season. Regularly remove any yellowed or dead leaves throughout the growing season. Avoid heavy pruning as this plant does not require extensive maintenance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Knotted Crane's-bill","description":"Geranium nodosum, the knotted crane's-bill, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Geraniaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Knotted Crane's-bill"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Geranium nodosum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10546,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cercocarpus montanus, commonly known as Mountain Mahogany, thrives in dry conditions, making it drought-tolerant once established. It requires minimal watering and prefers well-drained soil. In its natural habitat, it often receives sporadic rainfall, so simulate this by watering deeply but infrequently. Ensure the soil dries out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. During prolonged dry spells, young plants may benefit from occasional supplementary watering, but mature plants generally sustain themselves on natural rainfall. Overwatering can lead to poor growth or plant health issues, so err on the side of underwatering once established."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cercocarpus montanus thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers full sun, which provides it with the best growth conditions and encourages abundant flowering. In areas with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Generally, planting in a location where it receives at least 6 hours of sunlight per day will ensure healthy development. Adaptable to various environments, it tolerates partial shade but may not flower as prolifically. It's well-suited to rocky and dry soils where full sun can promote robust and vigorous growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cercocarpus montanus is mainly for shaping and controlling size, as it naturally has a dense growth habit. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to promote healthy growth. Light pruning can help maintain a desired shape and encourage bushier growth. Avoid heavy pruning, especially in late summer or fall, as this could stimulate new growth that might not harden off before winter. Since Mountain Mahogany is relatively slow-growing, minimal pruning is usually sufficient to keep it well-maintained."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alderleaf Mountain Mahogany","description":"Cercocarpus montanus is a North American species of shrub or small tree in the family Rosaceae native to northern Mexico and the western United States. It is known by the common names alder-leaf mountain-mahogany, alder-leaf cercocarpus, and true mountain-mahogany. The variety argenteus is commonly known as silverleaf mountain-mahogany.","family":null,"flower_color":"Cream","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Alderleaf Mountain Mahogany"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cercocarpus montanus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10942,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ficus benghalensis, commonly known as the Banyan tree, requires moderate watering. It's crucial to let the topsoil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, especially since it can be vulnerable to overwatering. Water thoroughly once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the growing season, maintain consistent moisture levels, but reduce watering frequency in the winter months when the plant's growth slows down. Be attentive to the plant's environment, as factors like sunlight and humidity can affect its watering needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ficus benghalensis thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sun can scorch its leaves, so it's best placed near a window where it receives filtered light throughout the day. In indoor settings, avoid placing it too close to glass which can amplify light intensity. If the plant doesn’t get enough light, it may become leggy, and its growth will slow down. Supplement with artificial plant lights if needed, especially in areas with less natural light. Ensure the plant is rotated periodically to allow even exposure on all sides, preventing uneven growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ficus benghalensis is vital to maintain its shape and manage its size, as it tends to grow quite large. Prune during the early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or diseased branches, as well as any cross-branching that might hinder airflow and light penetration. Trim back any overly long branches to promote a denser growth pattern. It’s essential to use sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts, which reduces plant stress and potential pest infestation. Regular pruning encourages a healthier and more aesthetically pleasing plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Indian banyan","description":"Ficus benghalensis, commonly known as the banyan, banyan fig and Indian banyan, is a tree native to the Indian Subcontinent. Specimens in India are among the largest trees in the world by canopy coverage.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["India","Sri Lanka","Bangladesh"],"other_name":["Indian banyan"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Ficus benghalensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10848,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Corylus avellana, commonly known as European hazel, prefers evenly moist soil but is relatively tolerant of short dry spells once established. Water young plants regularly to help establish a strong root system, particularly during the first two years. Mature plants generally require less frequent watering, except during prolonged periods of drought where supplemental watering may be necessary. Ensure that the soil is well-draining, as standing water can lead to root rot. Mulching around the base of the plant can help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Corylus avellana prefers full sun to partial shade for optimal growth and nut production. While it can tolerate varying light conditions, a location with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day is ideal. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from heat stress. Insufficient sunlight may result in reduced vigor and fewer nuts, so choose a planting site that balances exposure and protection based on your specific climate conditions. This will ensure the plant thrives and produces abundant nuts."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Corylus avellana is best done during the late winter or early spring when the plant is still dormant to minimize stress. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to encourage healthy growth and good air circulation. For a more bush-like form, cut back older stems at ground level to promote new shoot growth. To encourage more tree-like growth, periodically remove lower branches. Regular pruning also helps maintain a manageable size and shape for ornamental purposes. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common hazel","description":"Corylus avellana, the common hazel, is a species of hazel native to Europe and western Asia, from the British Isles south to Iberia, Greece, Turkey and Cyprus, north to central Scandinavia, and east to the central Ural Mountains, the Caucasus, and northwestern Iran. It is an important component of the hedgerows that were the traditional field boundaries in lowland England. The wood was traditionally grown as coppice, the poles cut being used for wattle-and-daub building and...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["common hazel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Corylus avellana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10445,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crataegus monogyna, commonly known as hawthorn, requires moderate watering, especially during the first few years after planting. In general, it is drought-tolerant once established, but young or newly planted trees should be watered regularly to help them establish a strong root system. Water deeply and infrequently to maintain soil moisture and ensure deep root growth. Avoid excessive watering as overwatering can lead to root rot or other issues. In dry seasons, monitor the soil moisture and water when the top inch of soil feels dry, and always ensure good drainage to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crataegus monogyna thrives in full sun locations, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and berry production. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun is crucial to develop dense foliage and abundant flowers, which eventually turn into the red berries hawthorns are known for. Planting in an area with good air circulation can also help in reducing the risk of fungal diseases. Avoid deep shade as it can lead to poor flowering and limited berry production, impacting the overall aesthetic and health of the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Crataegus monogyna should occur while the tree is dormant, usually in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches, as well as those that cross or rub against each other. Additionally, thin out any overcrowded branches to allow light and air to reach the center of the tree, which can help prevent fungal diseases. Regular pruning helps maintain the desired shape and size of the tree and promotes healthy growth. Hawthorns can also be pruned to form hedges by trimming back the previous year's growth by a third to encourage thick growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"common hawthorn","description":"Crataegus monogyna, known as common hawthorn or single-seeded hawthorn, is a species of hawthorn native to Europe, northwest Africa and western Asia. It has been introduced in many other parts of the world. It can be an invasive weed.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North Africa","Western Asia"],"other_name":["common hawthorn"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Apple scab","Fire blight"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Crataegus monogyna"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
